                        </span>\r\n                                        <span class=\"al-author-name-more js-flyout-wrap\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                                            <a 95616, USA</div>\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search-label\">\r\n        Search for other works by this author on:\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n<div class=\"info-card-search   // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n                                                <option       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121092602 id=\"121092602\" class=\"abstract-title\" >ABSTRACT</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The primary goals of the STRong lensing Insights into the Dark Energy Survey (STRIDES) collaboration are to measure the dark energy equation of state parameter and the free streaming length of dark matter. To this aim, STRIDES is discovering strongly lensed quasars in the imaging data of the Dark Energy Survey and following them up to measure time delays, high resolution imaging, and spectroscopy sufficient to construct accurate lens models. In this paper, we first present forecasts for STRIDES. Then, we describe the STRIDES classification scheme, and give an overview of the Fall 2016 follow-up campaign. We continue by detailing the results of two selection methods, the outlier selection technique and a morphological algorithm, and presenting lens models of a system that could possibly be a lensed quasar in an unusual configuration. We conclude with the summary statistics of the Fall 2016 campaign. Including searches presented in companion papers (Anguita et\u00a0al.; Ostrovski et\u00a0al.), STRIDES followed up 117 targets identifying 7 new strongly lensed systems, and 7 nearly identical quasars, which could be confirmed as lenses by the detection of the lens galaxy. 76 candidates were rejected and 27 remain otherwise inconclusive, for a success rate in the range of 6\u201335\u00a0per\u2009cent. This rate is comparable to that of previous searches like SDSS Quasar Lens Search even though the parent data set of STRIDES is purely photometric and our selection of candidates cannot rely on spectroscopic information.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: statistical&quot;\">methods: statistical</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"catalogues\">catalogues</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121092604 id=\"121092604\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In the four decades since the discovery of the first strongly lensed quasars (Walsh, Carswell &amp; Weymann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1979</a>; Weymann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib94\" data-open=\"bib94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1980</a>), they have morphed from an intellectual curiosity to a powerful and in some sense unique astrophysical tool (Courbin, Saha &amp; Schechter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). Three classes of applications make strongly lensed quasars especially valuable. First, by modelling how the light of the background quasar and its host galaxy is distorted one can reconstruct the distribution of luminous and dark matter in the deflector, and thus address fundamental astrophysical problems like the normalization of the stellar initial mass function (Pooley et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) and the abundance of dark matter subhaloes (Mao &amp; Schneider <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Metcalf &amp; Madau <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; Dalal &amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Nierenberg et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Nierenberg et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Birrer, Amara &amp; Refregier <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Secondly, by exploiting magnification, one can study in great detail the distant quasars, the properties of their accretion discs and host galaxies (Peng et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Ding et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Thirdly, by measuring time delays between the variable images and stellar kinematics of the deflector one can measure cosmic distances and thus cosmological parameters, especially the Hubble Constant (Refsdal <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1964</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>; Treu &amp; Koopmans <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Schneider &amp; Sluse <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Birrer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Treu &amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017a</a>; Shajib, Treu &amp; Agnello <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Tie &amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Unfortunately, most applications to date have been limited by the small number of known suitable systems. Lensed quasars, particularly the ones with four images that provide the most information, are rare on the sky (of order 0.1 per square degree at present-day typical survey depth and resolution; Oguri &amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). Therefore, successful searches for lensed quasars require searches over large solid angles (e.g. Browne et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and substantial follow up to weed out false positives.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Furthermore, not every lensed quasar system is suitable for every application: depending on the specifics of the lensing configuration and on the brightness of deflector and source, some systems contain significantly more information than others. Thus, in practice, every application of strongly lensed quasars to date has been limited to samples of one or two dozens at best.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The present generation of wide field imaging surveys provides an opportunity to make transformative measurements by increasing dramatically the sample of known lens quasars. Hundreds of strongly lensed quasars are hiding in the thousands of square degrees currently being imaged by the Dark Energy Survey (DES; and similarly, e.g. the Hyper-Suprime-Cam SSP Survey, the VST-ATLAS Survey), waiting to be discovered and followed up.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to exploit the bounty of data provided by DES, we have formed the STRIDES collaboration (STRong lensing Insights into Dark Energy Survey<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup>). The immediate goal of STRIDES is to identify and follow-up large numbers of multiply-imaged quasars motivated by two main science drivers: (i) study dark energy using gravitational time delays; (ii) study dark matter using flux ratio and astrometric anomalies. Additional science goals include the determination of the normalization of stellar mass-to-light ratios of massive early-type galaxies and the properties of accretion discs through the study of quasar microlensing (e.g. Motta et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">As we will show in this paper, STRIDES can in principle discover enough strongly lensed quasars to make substantial headway on both its two main science drivers. Strongly lensed quasars\u2019 main contribution to dark energy measurements is through the determination of absolute distances in the relatively low-redshift universe, and thus of the Hubble Constant <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> (Treu &amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). In turn, knowledge of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> is currently a limiting factor in the interpretation of cosmic microwave background data (Weinberg et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017a</a>). Current measurements of <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> based on the local distance ladder method reach \u223c2.4\u00a0per\u2009cent precision (Riess et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Riess et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>). The most recent time delay based measurements reach \u223c3.8\u00a0per\u2009cent with just three systems (Bonvin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017a</a>). Reaching 1\u00a0per\u2009cent equivalent precision on <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> is extremely important (Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Weinberg et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Treu &amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) and it will require \u223c40 lensed quasars (Jee et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Shajib, Treu &amp; Agnello <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) with data and models of quality equivalent to those presented by Suyu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), Rusu et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), Sluse et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), Wong et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), and Bonvin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017a</a>). Similarly, current limits on dark matter substructure are based on \u223c10 lenses (Dalal &amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Vegetti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Nierenberg et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Quadrupling the sample of viable quads will be a major step forwards in constraining the properties of dark matter (Gilman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finding lensed quasars in purely imaging data sets of the size of DES is an unprecedented task. It requires the development of new algorithms to identify candidates from the imaging data, and substantial investment of telescope time to follow up and confirm the candidates. In order to maximize completeness and purity, the collaboration is pursuing multiple independent approaches to identify candidate lenses. The lack of <em>u</em>-band imaging data in DES makes it particularly hard to identify Quasi-Stellar Objects (hereafter QSOs); therefore, many of the selection techniques combine DES imaging with <em>Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer</em> (<em>WISE</em>) photometry. The candidates are then followed up with spectroscopy and higher resolution imaging. Both are necessary to confirm the lensing nature of the systems and obtain the redshift and astrometry necessary for modelling and scientific exploitation. First results from the STRIDES programme have been presented by Agnello et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) and Lin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Once the candidates are confirmed, the best ones are selected for monitoring either with the 1.2\u2009m Euler Telescope or with the MPIA 2.2\u2009m Telescope at La Silla as part of the COSMOGRAIL network (Courbin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper has multiple aims. First, it provides an overview of the STRIDES programme and forecasts the number of expected lensed quasars to be found in the complete Dark Energy Survey (DES; Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>). The forecasts show that the DES area depth and resolution should be sufficient to more than double the current sample of known lensed quasars, providing new systems especially in the South hemisphere outside the area covered by previously largest search based on the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS; Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Secondly, this paper defines a candidate classification system, and various subclasses of inconclusive and contaminant sources (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>). The system will be applied throughout the collaboration with the goal to standardize the lens confirmation process and hopefully adopted by other investigators. Thirdly, this paper gives an overview of the Fall 2016 follow-up campaign (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>), listing the candidates selected by two techniques (Sections\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>) that did not yield any confirmed lens, except for a possible unusual quadruply imaged quasar. Companion papers in this series present the follow-up of candidate lensed QSOs selected using other techniques (Anguita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Ostrovski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), showing spectra and images for all confirmed lenses and otherwise promising inconclusive systems.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn2\" data-open=\"fn2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">2</a></sup> The fourth goal of this paper is to present the summary statistics of the 2016 follow-up campaign, combining the results from every search method, as discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7\"></span><a href=\"#sec7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">7</a>. Target selection for the 2016 campaign was based on early DES data sets, which did not cover the full depth and footprint of the survey. Thus, the Fall 2016 campaign statistics are not sufficient for a detailed comparison with the forecast for STRIDES. However, the follow-up statistics are sufficient for an assessment of the success rate and the completeness of the searches so far. Remarkably, the success rate is comparable to those of previous searches, even though no spectroscopic pre-selection or <em>u</em>-band imaging was available. A short summary concludes the paper in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec8\"></span><a href=\"#sec8\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">8</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">All magnitudes are given in the AB system, and a standard concordance cosmology with \u03a9<sub><em>m</em></sub> = 0.3, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Omega _\\Lambda =0.7$|\u2060</span>, and <em>h</em> = 0.7 is assumed when necessary.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121092614 id=\"121092614\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 FORECASTS FOR STRIDES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our forecasts for STRIDES use the OM10 mock lensed quasar catalogue of Oguri &amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). The reader is referred to the original paper and associated software repository<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn3\" data-open=\"fn3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">3</a></sup> for full details of how this basic catalogue was generated. Here, we give only a concise summary for the convenience of the reader. The deflector population is assumed to consist of early-type galaxies, which represent 80\u201390\u00a0per\u2009cent of the galaxy-scale lenses (Turner, Ostriker &amp; Gott <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1984</a>; Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008a</a>) and dominate the optical depth for image separations in the range of 0.5\u20134 arcsec considered here. We do not consider systems with smaller image separation, since they would be unresolved in the DES images. Systems with image separation larger than <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$4\\rm{\\,arcsec}$|</span> would be dominated by group- and cluster-scale lenses, and thus are not appropriately captured by the OM10 framework.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The deflector population is described by the velocity dispersion function of early-type galaxies (Choi, Park &amp; Vogeley <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), which has been shown to reproduce well the abundance of strong lenses (Chae <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Oguri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). The deflector potential is described by a single isothermal ellipsoid (Kormann, Schneider &amp; Bartelmann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1994</a>), which is the simplest model that gives a sufficiently accurate description of early-type galaxies (Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), with external shear to account for the contribution of the environment along the line of sight (Keeton, Kochanek &amp; Seljak <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>). Multiband fluxes based on the observed correlation between the velocity dispersion and luminosity of early-type galaxies (Hyde &amp; Bernardi <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) are computed using the publicly available code <span class=\"small-caps\">LensPop</span>,<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn4\" data-open=\"fn4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">4</a></sup> written by one of us (Collett <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The quasar source population is described by a redshift-dependent double power-law luminosity function consistent with SDSS data (Fan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; Richards et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> shows the expected number of multiply-imaged quasars as a function of total (unresolved) quasar <em>i</em>-band magnitude, given the 5000 square degree footprint. By combining all the lensed quasar light to compute each mock lens\u2019 total quasar brightness, we enable an approximate emulation of a catalogue-level selection in which no lens system is resolved into component multiple images, as is certainly the case for the <em>WISE</em> photometry (primarily <em>W</em>1 and <em>W</em>2, with resolution <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\sim }6\\, \\text{arcsec}$|\u2060</span>) that we use in our candidate selection. The number counts curves are truncated because the OM10 catalogue was generated so as to contain lens systems whose third brightest image would be detected at 10\u03c3 in a single LSST visit, with depth <em>i</em> = 24.5. This gives a mock sample bright enough for our purposes.</p>                        <a id=\"121092619\" scrollto-destination=\"121092619\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/m_sty2329fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&amp;Signature=4zRoQq-O3FNKU2C2X6ePCjRlMgUF3pREzxPSR6OloFoIIcl~ACtQBPRwyeOpOF0j216ZBO8ulObR5cVtc8i5Wmnci-16q-~fGtCjUht8kyvySrCBBsAktZbOoRqgXChQuEf8rH3qxVC87ZH5DG9~9Fedbwo~9ZeEDjgiqbwSgoKM9jjGWdeGpQk4D2-QwvUUgOqDPuiWqllv4gSXdzunLU~zWyVxExeCaukcvFJcWb9-9ISAQaEHrMStpCWs8oZALJqO3DlGq5iwx1HWNCp7--Ld7lhfoEyTkppP7SnErBDqPrqJmpmxyiY7qLdRPhTJ0Tij7XbDiCJjQS8EbYcxig__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cumulative number of expected lensed quasars for STRIDES based on the Oguri &amp; Marshall (2010) catalogue, in an approximate emulation of the STRIDES lens selection. Thick solid red lines represent quads, thin solid blue lines represent doubles. Top: expected number of lenses in the DES+WISE catalogues, as a function of total lensed quasar magnitude. Bottom: expected number of catalogue-selected lenses visible (i.e. resolved as lenses, with detectable counter-images) in the DES images.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121092619/sty2329fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121092619\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/sty2329fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&Signature=eP1C8h1kAcruM3UdPObp77Z4CdFal8PuDeuCwnp8N3d1qkegiQBhuCv7U2Xi~phTH3JR87DbjuqMdJOFkMRUF8ufvbTEFHJ7WfCKgJaumZrSd0fMCTOu-9u9rHFWNJkeZd6oX2RwS-6~TLNVw6gSHCxnE1WeJ-T9~D7ay9ppsh0qasQA8ApUyJ30JuvAOgzjp7tv9zziujOmQEgfceLfN0UMrwoaGNtVAskGyoBAX1Llszg7yXXPWjjlLwrcvVQk7p5JIYIXdMXs7TU1c6O~CaEqYT~OXz3xKGAHN0DA0PzAHJm5D1eu98SH8FWfH7DNHUNIcI2~gW7Ip1sV45ctOA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121092619&ar=5078885&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cumulative number of expected lensed quasars for STRIDES based on the Oguri &amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) catalogue, in an approximate emulation of the STRIDES lens selection. Thick solid red lines represent quads, thin solid blue lines represent doubles. Top: expected number of lenses in the DES+<em>WISE</em> catalogues, as a function of total lensed quasar magnitude. Bottom: expected number of catalogue-selected lenses visible (i.e. resolved as lenses, with detectable counter-images) in the DES images.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/m_sty2329fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&amp;Signature=4zRoQq-O3FNKU2C2X6ePCjRlMgUF3pREzxPSR6OloFoIIcl~ACtQBPRwyeOpOF0j216ZBO8ulObR5cVtc8i5Wmnci-16q-~fGtCjUht8kyvySrCBBsAktZbOoRqgXChQuEf8rH3qxVC87ZH5DG9~9Fedbwo~9ZeEDjgiqbwSgoKM9jjGWdeGpQk4D2-QwvUUgOqDPuiWqllv4gSXdzunLU~zWyVxExeCaukcvFJcWb9-9ISAQaEHrMStpCWs8oZALJqO3DlGq5iwx1HWNCp7--Ld7lhfoEyTkppP7SnErBDqPrqJmpmxyiY7qLdRPhTJ0Tij7XbDiCJjQS8EbYcxig__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cumulative number of expected lensed quasars for STRIDES based on the Oguri &amp; Marshall (2010) catalogue, in an approximate emulation of the STRIDES lens selection. Thick solid red lines represent quads, thin solid blue lines represent doubles. Top: expected number of lenses in the DES+WISE catalogues, as a function of total lensed quasar magnitude. Bottom: expected number of catalogue-selected lenses visible (i.e. resolved as lenses, with detectable counter-images) in the DES images.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121092619/sty2329fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121092619\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/sty2329fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&Signature=eP1C8h1kAcruM3UdPObp77Z4CdFal8PuDeuCwnp8N3d1qkegiQBhuCv7U2Xi~phTH3JR87DbjuqMdJOFkMRUF8ufvbTEFHJ7WfCKgJaumZrSd0fMCTOu-9u9rHFWNJkeZd6oX2RwS-6~TLNVw6gSHCxnE1WeJ-T9~D7ay9ppsh0qasQA8ApUyJ30JuvAOgzjp7tv9zziujOmQEgfceLfN0UMrwoaGNtVAskGyoBAX1Llszg7yXXPWjjlLwrcvVQk7p5JIYIXdMXs7TU1c6O~CaEqYT~OXz3xKGAHN0DA0PzAHJm5D1eu98SH8FWfH7DNHUNIcI2~gW7Ip1sV45ctOA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121092619&ar=5078885&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cumulative number of expected lensed quasars for STRIDES based on the Oguri &amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) catalogue, in an approximate emulation of the STRIDES lens selection. Thick solid red lines represent quads, thin solid blue lines represent doubles. Top: expected number of lenses in the DES+<em>WISE</em> catalogues, as a function of total lensed quasar magnitude. Bottom: expected number of catalogue-selected lenses visible (i.e. resolved as lenses, with detectable counter-images) in the DES images.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">From Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, we see that quad systems outnumber double systems at magnitudes brighter than <em>i</em> \u2248 16.6. While our actual photometric joint DES+<em>WISE</em> catalogue selection is complex, it leads to a \u2018Stage 1\u2019 list of candidates that is significantly incomplete below a total quasar magnitude of <em>i</em> \u2248 20.5. Above this limit, we expect the DES survey area to contain about 60 quads and 250 doubles.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">However, many of these systems will have multiple image separations that are too small to be resolved, and counter images that are too faint to see, and so we expect these to be ranked lowly in any imaging follow-up campaign. Requiring that the image separation be greater than 0.9 arcsec to be resolved in the DES survey images and that the second (in doubles) or third (in quads) brightest image to be detected above the DES Y3 detection limit of <em>i</em> = 23.4 emulates a \u2018Stage 2\u2019 image inspection selection that leads to a reduced number of <em>visibly</em> multiply-imaged quasars. We see from the lower panel of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> that we expect this Stage 2 sample to contain about 50 quads and 200 doubles for a total of about 250 potentially detectable lens systems.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To put the STRIDES forecasts in context, this Stage 2 sample is larger than all the currently published lensed quasars, i.e. approximately 40 quads and 140 doubles, including cluster scale deflectors.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">5</a></sup> We can also compare the STRIDES forecasts to the outcome of the SDSS searches and the expectations and results for the recently completed Kilo Degree Survey (KIDS; de Jong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). The SDSS Quasar Lens Search (SQLS; Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) reported 26 lensed quasars as part of their statistical sample (6 were known prior to SQLS), plus an additional 36 found with a variety of techniques (14 were known prior to SQLS). Of the 26 quads in the statistical sample, 4 are galaxy-scale quads (including one previously known) and one is a cluster-scale 5 image lens. Of the non-statistical sample, five systems have four or more images (four of which were previously known). The statistical sample is limited to a total quasar brightness of <em>i</em> &lt; 19.1, and the non-statistical sample extends to <em>i</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a020. As described above, DES should be able to deliver a significantly larger number of lenses by virtue of the superior depth and resolution of its images, even though the area covered on the sky is smaller than that of SDSS. Furthermore, the overlap between SDSS and DES is minimal, so the two searches are complementary in terms of sky coverage and follow-up opportunities. Similarly to DES, KIDS targets the southern hemisphere, but its smaller solid angle coverage limits the yield in terms of lenses. An approximate forecast can be obtained by scaling the DES predictions by the ratio of the sky coverage. Thus, KIDS Data Release 3 and 4 should find approximately 10\u00a0per\u2009cent and 20\u00a0per\u2009cent of the lenses present in DES (Spiniello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">An important caveat for the use of the sample for time delay cosmography is that the brightness of the faintest image in the system is the limiting factor for monitoring. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, we show the predicted number of lenses as a function of faintest image magnitude. From our COSMOGRAIL lens monitoring experience, we expect to be able to measure the time delay well for systems with faintest image brighter than <em>i</em> \u2248 20.2 and image separation larger than 0.9 arcsec, with the current allocation of 1\u2009m/2\u2009m class telescopes (going fainter would require more time on 1\u2009m/2\u2009m telescopes or upgrading to a 4\u2009m telescope; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). This practical limit leads to a prediction of there being about 15 quads and 45 doubles bright enough to monitor well in the DES area, with current monitoring capabilities. Exploiting the statistical power of the larger STRIDES sample of 50 quads and 200 doubles will require monitoring on 4\u2009m class telescopes, or much larger time allocations on the 1\u20132\u2009m class telescopes that are currently used. For example, COSMOGRAIL is currently using 20\u00a0per\u2009cent of the time on a 2.2\u2009m telescope (Courbin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"121092624\" scrollto-destination=\"121092624\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/m_sty2329fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&amp;Signature=n5iqlBKXoZGiPnvyoXpbS7l51Ejf5KQQqn0g9u95tMtEmQrthza~EMyPGHmPLjK00EakTb6Cgjvie-mooUGa2GCAd7H5C~N5fmLtUW47abIE2SF17PjZukJ~2eVSjfIgIU9d7tMjYk6civQTxifhwAli6xdoVZ37nvsRXnYV4eWheI1ZaxOroCfM-A2s9z46AOvIES~MARhNoTCI6kB7YbRngRL4dOiImKsWMaHzJBf8w5--aIZjCQzZ3MpoCe1dG9JVxL~Tfs01hERaELFMj8kKlMtPLA4keBDCg-PW19Fd5dE~SH02nyNT0zCHneYTLapfI9xLKAjA4y~ht6Vb3g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cumulative number of expected lensed quasars for STRIDES based on Oguri &amp; Marshall (2010) catalogue as a function of their faintest quasar image\u2019s magnitude. Thick solid red lines represent quads, and thin solid blue lines represent doubles. The practical limit for current monitoring capabilities are shown as a vertical dashed line.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121092624/sty2329fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121092624\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/sty2329fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&Signature=EO2kmwCHJyF3W~PnS-33HsjNY7eZa0d1lias0UEvBl-wKuw3AbavLnptD7zPLQuMilJUiEkUFpKK9PVnn9IVSVfgoVZdgW9MlobNyW1bViaFD8NfM~bgZkEzYZARDjMcS1EOPqELXxWHtw3akoQQiWQmLzUjRr6M7KQWxTnNlL34dUF0g9Q2P3rIc1TnR~j71Y1IM0fj9hC6L7Wq8kpmAlURLRpBC9RpX60XGNTIlRvAeu96X0L5M~SmdaEN-sp~aFJ59OA18zKbaFQFobYUYVdYLzxT0YUcmhf-YXZEW4j9Xq3UGEhYspBwYSFlapglcH4aSbUWXF-OdzBgDBV6Ng__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121092624&ar=5078885&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cumulative number of expected lensed quasars for STRIDES based on Oguri &amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) catalogue as a function of their faintest quasar image\u2019s magnitude. Thick solid red lines represent quads, and thin solid blue lines represent doubles. The practical limit for current monitoring capabilities are shown as a vertical dashed line.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/m_sty2329fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&amp;Signature=n5iqlBKXoZGiPnvyoXpbS7l51Ejf5KQQqn0g9u95tMtEmQrthza~EMyPGHmPLjK00EakTb6Cgjvie-mooUGa2GCAd7H5C~N5fmLtUW47abIE2SF17PjZukJ~2eVSjfIgIU9d7tMjYk6civQTxifhwAli6xdoVZ37nvsRXnYV4eWheI1ZaxOroCfM-A2s9z46AOvIES~MARhNoTCI6kB7YbRngRL4dOiImKsWMaHzJBf8w5--aIZjCQzZ3MpoCe1dG9JVxL~Tfs01hERaELFMj8kKlMtPLA4keBDCg-PW19Fd5dE~SH02nyNT0zCHneYTLapfI9xLKAjA4y~ht6Vb3g__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cumulative number of expected lensed quasars for STRIDES based on Oguri &amp; Marshall (2010) catalogue as a function of their faintest quasar image\u2019s magnitude. Thick solid red lines represent quads, and thin solid blue lines represent doubles. The practical limit for current monitoring capabilities are shown as a vertical dashed line.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121092624/sty2329fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121092624\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/sty2329fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&Signature=EO2kmwCHJyF3W~PnS-33HsjNY7eZa0d1lias0UEvBl-wKuw3AbavLnptD7zPLQuMilJUiEkUFpKK9PVnn9IVSVfgoVZdgW9MlobNyW1bViaFD8NfM~bgZkEzYZARDjMcS1EOPqELXxWHtw3akoQQiWQmLzUjRr6M7KQWxTnNlL34dUF0g9Q2P3rIc1TnR~j71Y1IM0fj9hC6L7Wq8kpmAlURLRpBC9RpX60XGNTIlRvAeu96X0L5M~SmdaEN-sp~aFJ59OA18zKbaFQFobYUYVdYLzxT0YUcmhf-YXZEW4j9Xq3UGEhYspBwYSFlapglcH4aSbUWXF-OdzBgDBV6Ng__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121092624&ar=5078885&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cumulative number of expected lensed quasars for STRIDES based on Oguri &amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) catalogue as a function of their faintest quasar image\u2019s magnitude. Thick solid red lines represent quads, and thin solid blue lines represent doubles. The practical limit for current monitoring capabilities are shown as a vertical dashed line.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The deflector magnitude is also an important consideration for constructing a cosmographic time delay lens sample, since it is a limiting factor in the determination of stellar kinematics used to break the mass-sheet degeneracy. The forecast as function of deflector magnitude is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. We compute lens galaxy magnitudes using the stellar population synthesis code provided with the <span class=\"small-caps\">LensPop</span> package (Collett <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). For a given velocity dispersion, we compute the absolute rest-frame <em>r</em>-band magnitude using the relation of Hyde &amp; Bernardi (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). This is then converted to observed apparent magnitudes using the redshift of the lens, a flat \u039bCDM cosmology with <em>h</em> = 0.7 and \u03a9<sub>M</sub> = 0.3, and assuming a 9\u00a0Gyr old population with solar metallicity. We use the LRIS and OSIRIS spectrographs at the Keck Observatory for the stellar kinematics measurements: we see that with these facilities we should expect <em>all</em> of our STRIDES systems to have easily measured lens galaxy stellar kinematics to 6\u20137\u00a0per\u2009cent precision, which is the current state of the art in this field (Wong et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"121092626\" scrollto-destination=\"121092626\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/m_sty2329fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&amp;Signature=2f7qHbqVirnpXrGjcgkjQKheF1W1EF2mLzgSKyNCRYmnQQN55Yy~K-FX8IeM8Mn0gt5-ysZpifQ6aY7abM4wgZw4DT8c5f~gGQepWZRmRwm71M5Ikt-UO9onv8i~1-3ICRFah5A5wv1j1F5yXzavdp0nKKkUjvtDwi1DnyVNZyhnj3iaXvzDbclFY8~Yojw8C9aNEDwiMyMZ0Eg9yerOAZ4n~-VJAS3oODoi5LZdgrhUEhC3FdmUP9RFem5YwtO9ky3e1QkDkIjiEBvVIXh4flWy2x~at4ORG7loJlAolNlkBQMhcHEQdAT6zyYm-t8Kzlegz7ySnFjZr-2~MuoHqg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cumulative number of expected lensed quasars for STRIDES based on Oguri &amp; Marshall (2010) catalogue as a function of deflector magnitude. Thick solid red lines represent quads, and thin solid blue lines represent doubles. The practical limit for velocity dispersion measurement based on current instruments on 8\u201310\u2009m ground based telescopes are shown as vertical dashed lines.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121092626/sty2329fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121092626\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/sty2329fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&Signature=Yn5vu~4zWy7A6oIdopGpouFxsGVyOfUUPPBodFIiqbfc~f4atASbMz2irvmEwxJWBtHUyb7Am5lIdwxxrOiJz~0YnXOdaZhWpBCdhcJzqVv-6s5zFKQejgXQdbTpy22GVPjnvkfLXw2EVRa7lzFMnHWH1X~uEZUBIbuehp391pgmo8G7ebSBTqNn7zBhaoL~tRroiG-PJ0dys3w0kJJR9JNzOKFLxXwKhgc-hvZ6NZGX5hDNqtvlJz3sVa7OAv7kLUosQg1HiVHMFa9kBfYvhyPAabPNCYClvmGRHiXcmwShXtszujR67YhAnkk3FedomxWkNoDJpRl4Mt7qMTbfxg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121092626&ar=5078885&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cumulative number of expected lensed quasars for STRIDES based on Oguri &amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) catalogue as a function of deflector magnitude. Thick solid red lines represent quads, and thin solid blue lines represent doubles. The practical limit for velocity dispersion measurement based on current instruments on 8\u201310\u2009m ground based telescopes are shown as vertical dashed lines.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/m_sty2329fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&amp;Signature=2f7qHbqVirnpXrGjcgkjQKheF1W1EF2mLzgSKyNCRYmnQQN55Yy~K-FX8IeM8Mn0gt5-ysZpifQ6aY7abM4wgZw4DT8c5f~gGQepWZRmRwm71M5Ikt-UO9onv8i~1-3ICRFah5A5wv1j1F5yXzavdp0nKKkUjvtDwi1DnyVNZyhnj3iaXvzDbclFY8~Yojw8C9aNEDwiMyMZ0Eg9yerOAZ4n~-VJAS3oODoi5LZdgrhUEhC3FdmUP9RFem5YwtO9ky3e1QkDkIjiEBvVIXh4flWy2x~at4ORG7loJlAolNlkBQMhcHEQdAT6zyYm-t8Kzlegz7ySnFjZr-2~MuoHqg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cumulative number of expected lensed quasars for STRIDES based on Oguri &amp; Marshall (2010) catalogue as a function of deflector magnitude. Thick solid red lines represent quads, and thin solid blue lines represent doubles. The practical limit for velocity dispersion measurement based on current instruments on 8\u201310\u2009m ground based telescopes are shown as vertical dashed lines.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121092626/sty2329fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121092626\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/sty2329fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&Signature=Yn5vu~4zWy7A6oIdopGpouFxsGVyOfUUPPBodFIiqbfc~f4atASbMz2irvmEwxJWBtHUyb7Am5lIdwxxrOiJz~0YnXOdaZhWpBCdhcJzqVv-6s5zFKQejgXQdbTpy22GVPjnvkfLXw2EVRa7lzFMnHWH1X~uEZUBIbuehp391pgmo8G7ebSBTqNn7zBhaoL~tRroiG-PJ0dys3w0kJJR9JNzOKFLxXwKhgc-hvZ6NZGX5hDNqtvlJz3sVa7OAv7kLUosQg1HiVHMFa9kBfYvhyPAabPNCYClvmGRHiXcmwShXtszujR67YhAnkk3FedomxWkNoDJpRl4Mt7qMTbfxg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121092626&ar=5078885&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cumulative number of expected lensed quasars for STRIDES based on Oguri &amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) catalogue as a function of deflector magnitude. Thick solid red lines represent quads, and thin solid blue lines represent doubles. The practical limit for velocity dispersion measurement based on current instruments on 8\u201310\u2009m ground based telescopes are shown as vertical dashed lines.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Other interesting properties of the expected sample are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. We expect the deflector redshift distribution to peak at around <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>d</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.5, while the sources peak at redshifts between <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub>s</sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02 and 3. As expected, the distribution of velocity dispersion of the deflector peaks around \u03c3\u00a0\u223c 250\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>, due to the exponential cut-off of the velocity dispersion function for large \u03c3 and the \u03c3<sup>4</sup> dependence of lensing cross-section.</p>                        <a id=\"121092628\" scrollto-destination=\"121092628\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/m_sty2329fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&amp;Signature=i-nxIB2v0H21iSRgI0PeHm7qDiW-cJ5zJRrkT-LpWl4zN3ITgOlDOMUaBJD0gBb3EGbbet5sTBRx2~9pERDZCVs9IYVaLJtcx5q0X8G7lu7ZBK0IVb4BYVFiUd4GcWVwCSIrGn2cTdZovXF9~uSVUOrCnbC9cZ5fubt9rAq6Jksml-VsKxkxW5ndGUbSMJWWbz2x5WLwHqHXmP2SiyZ5Oynmsn~3kWDfWpbJ~HW4Eq~lV1jPizYMgTuUsF1x~TO4CCxC5oztg7lPo7xF3XQ6dryZW~RFvKuJsVjcCNWIGU2hVTZLNaNCq9pyGw9vb3gaYDjJ8QKxbzc8Ws6HCwwJdA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of basic properties for the expected lensed quasar sample for STRIDES based on the Oguri &amp; Marshall (2010) catalogue. As in the other panels in this section, the more numerous doubles are shown in blue, while quads are shown in red. The histograms on the diagonal show 1D normalized probability distribution functions based on the samples.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121092628/sty2329fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121092628\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/sty2329fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&Signature=bdJFSyc7ApSwLE40vBb4cr9FvLiZ2ZrtM-d5HJRxpDPLJaURU6d9kfuGC22BhY-B~BeXKfOiJa~JDsI4TsSsfevYAIqS-QvH~rC5Fy1uiKDjPAjsnxlIqjW8AJbNgP6zShk6hotTbGBX~4BLx7352HVT7EbELfiDUV~tzUxumguqZHR2SQdcKysSoBZdA~0zm2UNej5o21rEMzXeSxi6lHcyE~D1XnBshYxaXiQPemdef8fYvrFWhG8IGOAwYpySVZFopd19t04LK0rdqoevQEtEKmKip561FkoOTTLYEoTIaftCpCqg6up0E7DCGYkKO84~iCOxiePLtFmXr2LtYQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121092628&ar=5078885&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of basic properties for the expected lensed quasar sample for STRIDES based on the Oguri &amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) catalogue. As in the other panels in this section, the more numerous doubles are shown in blue, while quads are shown in red. The histograms on the diagonal show 1D normalized probability distribution functions based on the samples.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/m_sty2329fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&amp;Signature=i-nxIB2v0H21iSRgI0PeHm7qDiW-cJ5zJRrkT-LpWl4zN3ITgOlDOMUaBJD0gBb3EGbbet5sTBRx2~9pERDZCVs9IYVaLJtcx5q0X8G7lu7ZBK0IVb4BYVFiUd4GcWVwCSIrGn2cTdZovXF9~uSVUOrCnbC9cZ5fubt9rAq6Jksml-VsKxkxW5ndGUbSMJWWbz2x5WLwHqHXmP2SiyZ5Oynmsn~3kWDfWpbJ~HW4Eq~lV1jPizYMgTuUsF1x~TO4CCxC5oztg7lPo7xF3XQ6dryZW~RFvKuJsVjcCNWIGU2hVTZLNaNCq9pyGw9vb3gaYDjJ8QKxbzc8Ws6HCwwJdA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of basic properties for the expected lensed quasar sample for STRIDES based on the Oguri &amp; Marshall (2010) catalogue. As in the other panels in this section, the more numerous doubles are shown in blue, while quads are shown in red. The histograms on the diagonal show 1D normalized probability distribution functions based on the samples.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121092628/sty2329fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121092628\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/sty2329fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&Signature=bdJFSyc7ApSwLE40vBb4cr9FvLiZ2ZrtM-d5HJRxpDPLJaURU6d9kfuGC22BhY-B~BeXKfOiJa~JDsI4TsSsfevYAIqS-QvH~rC5Fy1uiKDjPAjsnxlIqjW8AJbNgP6zShk6hotTbGBX~4BLx7352HVT7EbELfiDUV~tzUxumguqZHR2SQdcKysSoBZdA~0zm2UNej5o21rEMzXeSxi6lHcyE~D1XnBshYxaXiQPemdef8fYvrFWhG8IGOAwYpySVZFopd19t04LK0rdqoevQEtEKmKip561FkoOTTLYEoTIaftCpCqg6up0E7DCGYkKO84~iCOxiePLtFmXr2LtYQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121092628&ar=5078885&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of basic properties for the expected lensed quasar sample for STRIDES based on the Oguri &amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) catalogue. As in the other panels in this section, the more numerous doubles are shown in blue, while quads are shown in red. The histograms on the diagonal show 1D normalized probability distribution functions based on the samples.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121092629 id=\"121092629\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 STRIDES CLASSIFICATION SCHEME AND CRITERIA</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we define the STRIDES classification scheme for confirmed lenses, inconclusive systems, and contaminants. Although some degree of subjectivity is inherent in this classification, we will strive to keep a consistent classification scheme throughout the STRIDES follow-up campaigns in 2016 and future years. In general, we find that both high-resolution imaging and spectroscopy are necessary to classify a system as a definite lens, except in the following cases: imaging is sufficient if arcs are detected or if the configuration is consistent with a classic quad configuration (cross, fold, cusp). Spectroscopy is sufficient if the quasar spectra are partially resolved and a deflector galaxy is detected in between.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=121092631 id=\"121092631\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Secure, probable, and possible lenses</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We adopt a different classification scheme for doubles and quads, as detailed below.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121092633 id=\"121092633\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-1>3.1.1 Confirmed lenses</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">For doubles, we require for confirmation one of the following scenarios: (1) nearly identical spectra of the two quasar images (i.e. differences consistent with microlensing and differential dust extinction), as well as the detection of the lens galaxy in imaging or spectroscopy; (2) the detection of gravitationally lensed arcs consistent with extended images of the quasar host galaxy; and (3) coherent and delayed variability (although in general the DES data do not sample enough epochs to classify according to this criterion).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For quads, given the intrinsic rarity of the configuration (and possible contaminants) and the difficulty of detecting the deflector galaxy and separating the lensed quasar images in spectroscopy, we only require spectroscopic confirmation of at least one of the quasar images, the detection of flux consistent with a lens galaxy, plus a configuration consistent with strong lensing. The latter could consist, e.g. of three point sources, plus an extended source interpreted as the fourth image blended with the deflector, or other similar configurations.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121092636 id=\"121092636\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1-2>3.1.2 Probable and possible quads</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We use these categories for candidate quads that do not fulfil all criteria for confirmation. Again, this classification is inherently subjective, involving some personal judgement of what is a satisfactory lens model and lens galaxy detection. It is similar in spirit to the classification (secure, probable, possible) adopted by the SLACS Team (Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008b</a>; Auger et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>). In an attempt to quantify the degree of certainty, we consider secure systems that have 99\u00a0per\u2009cent probability of being lenses, probable at 95\u00a0per\u2009cent, and possible at 68\u00a0per\u2009cent, whenever such quantification is possible.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=121092638 id=\"121092638\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Inconclusive systems</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Inconclusive systems include candidate doubles that have a significant likelihood of being lenses based on the available good-quality data, and those for which the data are just insufficient to make any statement.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121092640 id=\"121092640\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2-1>3.2.1 Nearly identical pairs of quasars</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We call nearly identical quasars (NIQs), every pair of spectroscopically confirmed quasars, for which spectral differences can be explained via microlensing or differential extinction, but there is no detection of a deflector galaxy. The non-detection can be due to insufficiently deep high-resolution imaging data or spectroscopy, or could be due to the system being composed of an actual physical pair as opposed to two lensed images. We single out this class of systems as primary targets for additional follow-up. Conversely, if the data are deep enough to rule out the presence of a lens galaxy, estimated in the following manner, the system is classified as not a lens. First, we take half the image separation as best estimate of the Einstein radius. Secondly, as a function of source and deflector redshift, the Einstein radius is transformed into stellar velocity dispersion \u03c3<sub>*</sub>, adopting a singular isothermal sphere model with normalization \u03c3<sub>SIS</sub> equal to \u03c3<sub>*</sub> (e.g. Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>). We limit the range of acceptable redshifts to those that yield \u03c3<sub>*</sub> &lt; 500\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>. Thirdly, we assign an apparent magnitude to each set of deflector redshift \u03c3<sub>*</sub> using the empirical relation for early type galaxies given by Mason et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Fourthly, we adopt the maximum of the possible magnitudes as faintest possible flux from the source. This magnitude is typically fainter than what we can reach in our standard ground based follow-up and usually requires deep/high resolution data from <em>HST</em> or adaptive optics (AO), since the lens galaxy could be hiding under the bright quasar in ground based seeing limited images.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=121092642 id=\"121092642\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2-2>3.2.2 Otherwise inconclusive doubles</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This class contains all other cases of candidate doubles where the quality of the data is insufficient to confirm or rule out the lensing hypothesis. This may include systems that look like doubles, but there is spectroscopic confirmation of just one putative image (or blended), or systems that are consistent with doubles in higher resolution imaging (from space or AO), but do not show arcs or have sufficiently good spectroscopy to confirm them as lenses.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=121092644 id=\"121092644\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Contaminants</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Whenever possible we classify false positive doubly imaged quasars in one of the following, mostly self-explanatory, classes: (1) quasar-star pair; (2) quasar pair; (3) quasar-galaxy pair, either based on spectroscopic classification or based on one of the two candidate images being resolved at resolution higher than that of the discovery images and inconsistent with lensed arcs; (4) galaxy pair or merging/irregular galaxy, either based on spectroscopic classification or based on the two candidate images being resolved at resolution higher than that of the discovery image and inconsistent with lensed arcs; (5) other.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121092646 id=\"121092646\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 OVERVIEW OF THE FALL 2016 FOLLOW-UP CAMPAIGN</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Based on the definitions introduced in the previous section, for definite confirmation we require the spectra of the multiple imaged quasars to be almost identical, although not exactly the same in order to allow for differences due to variability, microlensing, and line-of-sight effects. In addition, we require the detection of a main deflector galaxy, either photometrically or through foreground spectroscopic features. Alternatively, high-resolution imaging alone is sufficient if the system is a classic quad or arcs are detected.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Motivated by the goal to identify/reject as many candidates as possible we applied for telescope time for both AO imaging and spectroscopy. We applied to 3\u201310\u2009m class telescopes chosen based on instrument configuration and time availability during semester 2016B, such that the entire DES footprint was available. Our proposals were successful even though we had limited control over when the runs were scheduled. The criteria of the target choice and scheduling for each run are given below.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The telescopes and instruments used during the campaign and the dates of each run are summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. The 3.6\u2009m New Technology Telescope at La Silla was used primarily for spectroscopy. EFOSC2 was used with the #13 grism and 1.2 arcsec wide slit. The detector was binned two by two, resulting in a dispersion of 5.44\u00a0\u00c5\u2009pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>, a pixel scale of 0.24 arcsec along the slit, and wavelength coverage from 3685 to 9315\u2009\u00c5. Typically, one or two exposures of 600\u2009s were taken for each object. The 4.1\u2009m Southern Astrophysical Research Telescope at Cerro Pachon was used primarily for high-resolution imaging with its AO system SAM. Imaging was taken with the CCD SAMI through the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span>-band to maximize AO correction and optimize the contrast between quasar and deflector galaxy. The pixel scale was 0.045\u2009arcsec\u2009pixel<sup>\u22121</sup> (with a 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a02 binning yielding 0.09\u2009arcsec pixel<sup>\u22121</sup>) and the typical exposure time was 3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0180\u00a0s. When the weather was not conducive to AO imaging, SOAR was used with the Goodman Spectrograph to take spectra. For the Goodman set-up, we used the 400 lines\u2009mm<sup>\u22121</sup> grating with the blocking filter GG455, with a binning of 2\u00a0\u00d7\u00a02 and a slit width of 1 arcsec. Between two and three exposures of 1200\u00a0s were taken per target.</p>                        <a id=\"121092650\" scrollto-destination=\"121092650\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" 20\u201321\u00a0</td><td>Keck-2\u00a0</td><td>NIRC2\u00a0</td><td>Treu\u00a0</td><td>0\u00a0</td><td>Technical issues and weather losses\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Sep 25\u201328\u00a0</td><td>NTT\u00a0</td><td>EFOSC2\u00a0</td><td>Anguita\u00a0</td><td>37\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Oct 29\u201331\u00a0</td><td>Shane 3\u2009m\u00a0</td><td>ShARCS\u00a0</td><td>Rusu\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>Lost to weather\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Nov 19\u201320\u00a0</td><td>Keck-2\u00a0</td><td>ESI\u00a0</td><td>Fassnacht\u00a0</td><td>8\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Dec 3\u20136\u00a0</td><td>NTT\u00a0</td><td>EFOSC2\u00a0</td><td>Anguita\u00a0</td><td>40\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Dec 3\u20138\u00a0</td><td>SOAR\u00a0</td><td>SAMI\u00a0</td><td>Motta/Treu\u00a0</td><td>60\u00a0</td><td>Poor weather on Dec 8\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>Dec 16\u00a0</td><td>Keck-2\u00a0</td><td>NIRC2\u00a0</td><td>Treu\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>Lost to weather\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/121092650\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The 10\u2009m Keck-2 Telescope was used to follow-up the candidates visible from Maunakea, both for spectroscopy with the Echellette Spectrograph and Imager (ESI) and for imaging with the Near InfraRed Camera 2 behind the AO system. ESI was used in the default Echellette mode with the 1 arcsec slit, while NIRC2 was used in the narrow field configuration (10\u2009mas pixel) in the <em>K</em> band in order to maximize AO correction. One AO run was scheduled on the 3\u2009m Shane Telescope aimed for the brighter candidates but was lost to weather.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Outside of the main campaign, a few images and spectra were obtained with the 6.5 Magellan Telescopes. Those will be discussed in the appropriate context in papers II and III. <em>i</em>-band images of candidate DESJ2346-5203 were obtained with GMOS on the 8.1\u2009m Gemini South telescope as a part of fast turnaround programme GS-2016B-FT-17. The GMOS images are discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.1</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The number of DES targets (selected from SV, Y1, Y3 Dark Energy Survey Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Drlica-Wagner et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Abbott et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) observed in each run is given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. Non-DES targets were also observed and those are described elsewhere (e.g. Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>; Ostrovski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Williams et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Since both imaging and spectroscopy are generally required for confirmation, and our runs were tightly scheduled during the Fall 2016 DES visibility season, we adopted a running prioritization scheme. Observations of hitherto unobserved candidates were random, subject to airmass constraints. Once a candidate was observed, either in imaging or in spectroscopy, a quick assessment was made, generally the night of the observations or the next day. If the candidate could be ruled out based on the available data it was dropped from the target list. If it was confirmed, or considered promising (e.g. NIQ in spectroscopy or two point sources with an extended source in the middle in imaging), its priority was raised for the subsequent complementary runs. The coordinates and follow-up outcome of targets observed during the Fall 2016 are given in Tables\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> for two of the selection techniques and in companion papers II and III for the other techniques.</p>                        <a id=\"121092654\" scrollto-destination=\"121092654\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Summary of observed targets selected with the OST.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>i</em> Mag<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>SpecObs<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>ImaObs<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Notes<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>DESJ234628.18-520331.6\u00a0</td><td>20.00\u00a0</td><td>NTT 9/21, 9/25\u00a0</td><td>GEMINI 12/6\u00a0</td><td>Poss. a quad; SOAR: two point sources. Two stars\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DESJ044538.42-582847.0\u00a0</td><td>19.82\u00a0</td><td>NTT 12/5\u00a0</td><td>SOAR 12/5\u00a0</td><td>Contam. SOAR: two point sources. Two stars\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DESJ045613.66-582519.6\u00a0</td><td>20.10\u00a0</td><td>NTT 12/4\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>Contam. galaxies\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DESJ050713.60-584440.0\u00a0</td><td>20.53\u00a0</td><td>NTT 12/4\u00a0</td><td>SOAR 12/4\u00a0</td><td>Contam.
