Emission line galaxy + faint object\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DESJ053239.19-584823.0\u00a0</td><td>20.37\u00a0</td><td>NTT 12/3\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>Contam. Two stars\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>DESJ061727.03-482426.9\u00a0</td><td>18.91\u00a0</td><td>NTT 12/5\u00a0</td><td>SOAR 12/3\u00a0</td><td>Contam. Two stars\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/121092655\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121092656 id=\"121092656\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 FOLLOW-UP OF TARGETS SELECTED WITH THE OUTLIER SELECTION TECHNIQUE</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Twenty-six targets selected with the outlier selection technique (OST) introduced by Agnello (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) were observed during the Fall 2016 campaign. The candidates are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> together with a summary of the follow-up data and outcome.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">15 candidates were identified as contaminants, 10 could not be securely classified based on the available data and are thus considered inconclusive. For one system, the spectroscopy and morphology are possibly consistent with it being a quadruply imaged quasar in an usual configuration, although confirmation will require <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> or AO imaging, given the small image separation of the system. The system is described in detail in the Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec5-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5.1</a> along with a potential lens model. The success rate of this sample ranges between 0 and 42\u00a0per\u2009cent, depending on how many of the inconclusive candidates are actual lens systems, including the possible quad.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Two classes of contaminants stand out: (i) low redshift star-forming galaxies (7/26, i.e. 27\u00a0per\u2009cent); QSO+star pair (at least 6/26, i.e. 23\u00a0per\u2009cent). Both classes of objects are expected to be potential contaminants in photometrically selected samples (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Williams, Agnello &amp; Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and improved algorithms are required to reduce this source of contamination. QSO+star pairs were also common contaminants in SQLS. Low-redshift star-forming galaxies were less common in SQLS probably by virtue of the spectroscopic pre-selection and the availability of <em>u</em>-band photometry in SDSS.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Overall, this method did not produce any confirmed lens during the Fall 2016 campaign, even though it has been applied with success to other data sets (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018b</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">c</a>). Given the small numbers of targets involved, the low yield in this campaign could simply be a statistical fluctuation. In any case, there is certainly scope for improving the rejection of contaminants noted above.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=121092661 id=\"121092661\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>5.1 A candidate quad: lens models and discussion of the case of DESJ2346-5203</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The NTT spectra of DESJ2346-5203 (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>) are consistent with a small separation (subarcsecond separation) lens. The candidate deflector is an emission-line galaxy at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub><em>d</em></sub> = 0.48, while the source is a QSO at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub><em>s</em></sub> = 1.87. The distance between the two traces is approximately 2\u20133 pixels (i.e. <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.48\\text{--}0.72\\, \\text{arcsec}$|\u2060</span>) along the slit (position angle 20<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\, \\deg$|</span> east of north). Unfortunately, the resolution of the DES imaging data was not sufficient to confirm it as a lens. Therefore, we obtained high-resolution imaging data (3\u00a0\u00d7\u00a0263\u2009s exposures) using the Gemini South Telescope in excellent seeing, through a fast turnaround programme.</p>                        <a id=\"121092663\" scrollto-destination=\"121092663\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/m_sty2329fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&amp;Signature=LH8BsZk6AJAgaU1zWr6rE2IstsNsO2ScuANZOF-0O~4LaAGa~5gXudeiM~C3rIQtSHc7phQugPL~KPglNj4VQYxBZJtN6S8s3rKiuQUbKV~TxruafXCZWZg~gUuGnW4a0SEYn-tJxMNvqcR0TseheqR5WQ~esE0lns~gni-ReQGjCHxVHh1ZdpzMynXFI20r1M0XrUHKgxUTSYzc~Oy7DhnArda2NnBPaoUmjbLCiqp3RmU3-dtX9VtyBWmpa60B4O~u7GQJo5dYodLSfdgGo5tMm4lJNMJp86Kl2MC2sFLgw73KkAJEIvP0kx4oEGgsq4qMFKGp9VSUUk2HYib1kg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"NTT spectrum of DESJ2346-5203 taken on 2016 September 25. The single spectrum clearly shows emission lines at multiple redshifts. Top: 2D spectrum. Note the broad C\u2009iv and Mg\u2009ii emission and the different spatial extent of C\u2009iii] and [O\u2009ii]. Bottom: extracted 1D spectrum.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121092663/sty2329fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121092663\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/sty2329fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&Signature=SsbXuCabC1JbSuHQ89Sq6HMauNncNIr2u14DByoArTdpyJmpDS3N1mi-tPjgDGk1Qg9il4RDsYd7AV4VjOgcJipoqYNvDEIz8rHOviZKfVpaINlnLyPld2pnQatZNKdq7WT~UoZjNM46RCu0YDpy08b3L-Ol5yJ7F6vRWA2LUZxUMk1JROvaRe4wl7Ai-xP3iiYYZ9f5rscSLzH6N1gGZ5Iy-jzYJjM-B6HSxcbt7ZOf6rJkNPtFtUBR2sNm3u7ivqPtZpD6oZfTgLMRlNF4zqZS~FWE9bjCci~gJAVY9-BWfIxYnq26ig1-IW~RvIZD5xYwpEcx8vs-IEwSY2dy3g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121092663&ar=5078885&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">NTT spectrum of DESJ2346-5203 taken on 2016 September 25. The single spectrum clearly shows emission lines at multiple redshifts. Top: 2D spectrum. Note the broad C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> and Mg\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> emission and the different spatial extent of C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]. Bottom: extracted 1D spectrum.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/m_sty2329fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&amp;Signature=LH8BsZk6AJAgaU1zWr6rE2IstsNsO2ScuANZOF-0O~4LaAGa~5gXudeiM~C3rIQtSHc7phQugPL~KPglNj4VQYxBZJtN6S8s3rKiuQUbKV~TxruafXCZWZg~gUuGnW4a0SEYn-tJxMNvqcR0TseheqR5WQ~esE0lns~gni-ReQGjCHxVHh1ZdpzMynXFI20r1M0XrUHKgxUTSYzc~Oy7DhnArda2NnBPaoUmjbLCiqp3RmU3-dtX9VtyBWmpa60B4O~u7GQJo5dYodLSfdgGo5tMm4lJNMJp86Kl2MC2sFLgw73KkAJEIvP0kx4oEGgsq4qMFKGp9VSUUk2HYib1kg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"NTT spectrum of DESJ2346-5203 taken on 2016 September 25. The single spectrum clearly shows emission lines at multiple redshifts. Top: 2D spectrum. Note the broad C\u2009iv and Mg\u2009ii emission and the different spatial extent of C\u2009iii] and [O\u2009ii]. Bottom: extracted 1D spectrum.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121092663/sty2329fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121092663\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/sty2329fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&Signature=SsbXuCabC1JbSuHQ89Sq6HMauNncNIr2u14DByoArTdpyJmpDS3N1mi-tPjgDGk1Qg9il4RDsYd7AV4VjOgcJipoqYNvDEIz8rHOviZKfVpaINlnLyPld2pnQatZNKdq7WT~UoZjNM46RCu0YDpy08b3L-Ol5yJ7F6vRWA2LUZxUMk1JROvaRe4wl7Ai-xP3iiYYZ9f5rscSLzH6N1gGZ5Iy-jzYJjM-B6HSxcbt7ZOf6rJkNPtFtUBR2sNm3u7ivqPtZpD6oZfTgLMRlNF4zqZS~FWE9bjCci~gJAVY9-BWfIxYnq26ig1-IW~RvIZD5xYwpEcx8vs-IEwSY2dy3g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121092663&ar=5078885&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig5.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">NTT spectrum of DESJ2346-5203 taken on 2016 September 25. The single spectrum clearly shows emission lines at multiple redshifts. Top: 2D spectrum. Note the broad C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span> and Mg\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span> emission and the different spatial extent of C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>] and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]. Bottom: extracted 1D spectrum.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to investigate whether the system is quadruply imaged or not, we fit a lens model to the GEMINI GMOS-S data. We use a singular isothermal ellipsoid with additional external shear as the deflector mass model, elliptical Sersic profiles for the extended source galaxy and the lens galaxy and point sources with fixed relative magnifications based on the lens model for the quasar images. The PSF is estimated from a bright star in the image. We note that the PSF of the exposure is highly elliptical. The modelling is performed with the lens model software <span class=\"small-caps\">lenstronomy</span> (based on Birrer, Amara &amp; Refregier <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Birrer &amp; Amara <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>, available at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://github.com/sibirrer/lenstronomy\" target=\"_blank\">https://github.com/sibirrer/lenstronomy</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The lens model reproduces the image configuration reasonably well. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> shows a possible lens model of the candidate DESJ2346-5203. Interestingly, the reconstruction requires extra flux at the position of the deflector, consistent with the detection of the deflector. The lens model is almost spherical to match the rather unusual image configuration of two very nearby bright images (C and D) with a circularized Einstein radius of approximately <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$0.61\\, \\text{arcsec}$|\u2060</span>. The small image separation and the emission line suggest that if the system is a lens, the deflector is a late-type galaxy, and thus not one of the more common early-type deflectors considered in our forecasts.</p>                        <a id=\"121092666\" scrollto-destination=\"121092666\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/m_sty2329fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&amp;Signature=TYF3Ssojp0Shucep5SylXVFwBKvSAxYfEpNQi20HFVNJijD~1XkjVKLQeevxSQEmay2ENKN4hJEHJquxTQ-sb6F-~KD-f5dgDN6qQpJfd3G7fR3BGy-FsmpRRG9h3yc27mvGhNLDEnqXblG7wz4FC2Fc2pOA3J4oT7z9mYJOck8LPwl6DliXe3W~nzuy0JtAZ4csnWH0L1mkjC5IPzXMb4Biv~3VgMBmSPOkkuS2-gaCvbwq8au7AJmjd~AyAdqJmsMbq5xYW99k~bHIHI5~MU9deLW~7NNTer4WresBrZHzZDTMyKTTGoBr7Kh0Hl-am4fh9XHydK9pkCfSFLUmoQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"A lens model for the quad candidate DESJ2346-5203. Upper left: The reduced GEMINI image data. Upper middle: Image reconstruction. Upper right: Normalized residuals of the model compared to the data. Lower left: Source reconstruction. Lower middle: Lens light reconstruction. Lower right: Magnification model.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121092666/sty2329fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121092666\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/sty2329fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&Signature=Nxb5RgJ7RJAW1AlU-Xq6TRAqiRkSGNmvhEtr1RSwcNF-Ow8mPLMdXGrsMk7P8B8WvJG4IEystv39LtYvqKspElrhyZbVISZvf1MbhR8vuNCQZq~xln3zbfaF2QRWewWGXdpCBiUUoHhVjX3zG7XZgMsCcLGM3DDuxVHkps2L1NPI9u2v9ZiP~W~Khrh7GkYX7-wDoa~KvGuxRJAEwz3OzmubzgvpXq6rQ2j5O7q7FUKh-~V9VUWiG1ZFVuDxDgY~elRWehG3t4UqQH0zQAOxRqVvMMyGMtXO7h8In4Zc28hHVZYXzIeRiqnAokR7qWgvmEDzcl~wmSMJDxPTCuuuQg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121092666&ar=5078885&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">A lens model for the quad candidate DESJ2346-5203. Upper left: The reduced GEMINI image data. Upper middle: Image reconstruction. Upper right: Normalized residuals of the model compared to the data. Lower left: Source reconstruction. Lower middle: Lens light reconstruction. Lower right: Magnification model.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/m_sty2329fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&amp;Signature=TYF3Ssojp0Shucep5SylXVFwBKvSAxYfEpNQi20HFVNJijD~1XkjVKLQeevxSQEmay2ENKN4hJEHJquxTQ-sb6F-~KD-f5dgDN6qQpJfd3G7fR3BGy-FsmpRRG9h3yc27mvGhNLDEnqXblG7wz4FC2Fc2pOA3J4oT7z9mYJOck8LPwl6DliXe3W~nzuy0JtAZ4csnWH0L1mkjC5IPzXMb4Biv~3VgMBmSPOkkuS2-gaCvbwq8au7AJmjd~AyAdqJmsMbq5xYW99k~bHIHI5~MU9deLW~7NNTer4WresBrZHzZDTMyKTTGoBr7Kh0Hl-am4fh9XHydK9pkCfSFLUmoQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"A lens model for the quad candidate DESJ2346-5203. Upper left: The reduced GEMINI image data. Upper middle: Image reconstruction. Upper right: Normalized residuals of the model compared to the data. Lower left: Source reconstruction. Lower middle: Lens light reconstruction. Lower right: Magnification model.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121092666/sty2329fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121092666\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/sty2329fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&Signature=Nxb5RgJ7RJAW1AlU-Xq6TRAqiRkSGNmvhEtr1RSwcNF-Ow8mPLMdXGrsMk7P8B8WvJG4IEystv39LtYvqKspElrhyZbVISZvf1MbhR8vuNCQZq~xln3zbfaF2QRWewWGXdpCBiUUoHhVjX3zG7XZgMsCcLGM3DDuxVHkps2L1NPI9u2v9ZiP~W~Khrh7GkYX7-wDoa~KvGuxRJAEwz3OzmubzgvpXq6rQ2j5O7q7FUKh-~V9VUWiG1ZFVuDxDgY~elRWehG3t4UqQH0zQAOxRqVvMMyGMtXO7h8In4Zc28hHVZYXzIeRiqnAokR7qWgvmEDzcl~wmSMJDxPTCuuuQg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121092666&ar=5078885&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">A lens model for the quad candidate DESJ2346-5203. Upper left: The reduced GEMINI image data. Upper middle: Image reconstruction. Upper right: Normalized residuals of the model compared to the data. Lower left: Source reconstruction. Lower middle: Lens light reconstruction. Lower right: Magnification model.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The model is also consistent with a non-zero extended source that forms an Einstein ring configuration, although much fainter in brightness than the point sources. There are residuals left between the reconstructed model and the image. Some of them can be attributed to a potentially anomalous flux ratio between the point sources due to microlensing of stars. We also attempted to model the system as a doubly-imaged quasar (images A and C+D being a single image)+quadruply image host galaxy, similar to the case of SDSSJ1206+4332 (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). No good fit could be found for relatively simple mass models like elliptical power laws.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Additional information can be gathered by deconvolving the Gemini images using techniques developed by one of us (FC). The deconvolved image shows that image A is consistent with being point like, while images CD are well described by a single-point source, in the sense that if they are two merging images they must be unresolved at the resolution of this image. Image B is not well described by a point source. Subtracting the point sources in the deconvolved images does not show a significant excess consistent with a putative lens galaxy, although of course it could be present below the noise level.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Based on the spectroscopy, the lens model, and the deconvolved images, we conclude that DESJ2346-5203 is unlikely to be a strong lens system in a simple traditional configuration (e.g. four images of a quasar with a galaxy in between). The lens model leaves substantial residuals and is somewhat contrived with images C and D being practically on top of each other. However, we note that unusual morphologies (Orban de Xivry &amp; Marshall <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), or cases with extreme flux ratio anomalies like the one presented by Lin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) are difficult to rule out (or identify!) without higher resolution imaging or spatially resolved spectroscopy.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121092670 id=\"121092670\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 FOLLOW-UP OF TARGETS SELECTED WITH THE MORPHOLOGICAL ALGORITHM</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We also followed up a set of candidates identified via a morphological algorithm that was originally developed by two high-school students (Sivakumar &amp; Sivakumar <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) to search for quasars in the SDSS. This algorithm uses a set of morphological cuts followed by the application of image segmentation algorithms to find lensed quasar candidates. An initial set of objects were selected by applying the following criteria to all objects from the DES Y1A1_COADD (Morganson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Y1 means year one). <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Dec. <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\gt -60\\deg$|</span> to avoid the Magellanic Clouds.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to eliminate extended sources, we require that the Petrosian radius be less than 5 pixels, i.e. <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1.35\\, \\text{arcsec}$|\u2060</span>.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">To select objects with quasar-like colours, we then apply colour cuts \u22120.2495 &lt; <em>g</em> \u2212 <em>r</em> &lt; 0.3393, \u22120.3158 &lt; <em>r</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> &lt; 0.658, \u22120.239 &lt; <em>i</em> \u2212 <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> &lt; 0.591, similar<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn6\" data-open=\"fn6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">6</a></sup> to those implemented by Richards et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>) and converted to DES colours using the equations in appendix A.4 of Drlica-Wagner et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). All magnitudes are MAG_AUTO as calculated by <span class=\"small-caps\">SExtractor</span> (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Bertin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>).</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We require 17 &lt; <em>g</em> &lt; 22 and 17 &lt; <em>r</em> &lt; 22. The upper cut eliminates saturated objects and the lower one removes faint galaxies that can be misclassified as stars.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The object detection in DES (Bertin &amp; Arnouts <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Bertin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>) does not de-blend the individual components of small image separation lensed quasars into separate objects. These blended objects appear as extended sources and can be identified by requiring that the magnitude measured assuming a stellar profile, MAG_PSF, be different from MAG_AUTO, namely <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\text{ABS}(r_{\\rm MAG\\_AUTO} - r_{\\rm MAG\\_PSF})\\gt 0.12$|\u2060</span>.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, we require that the objects have FLAGS_G =1 or FLAGS_G = 3. This selects objects that have neighbours or neighbours and blended. This eliminates the many objects that are isolated. Additionally, we require FLAGS_G &lt;4 and FLAGS_R &lt;4 to eliminate objects that contain any saturated pixels.</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">These cuts select 112\u2009820 candidates. We then obtain postage stamp images of each candidate and run image segmentation algorithms on them to identify individual components in the images. Two algorithms were used for this step, the marker-controlled watershed (Beucher <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>) and the random walker (Grady <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), with implementations modified from those in the <span class=\"small-caps\">python scikit-image</span> package (van der Walt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). The marker-controlled watershed algorithm operates on binary images so the colour postage stamps were first converted to black and white using adaptive thresholding. A distance function was defined to identify seeds in the image that correspond to the images to be extracted. These seeds provide the locations from which the algorithm floods the image to find distinct boundaries, and this method avoids oversegmentation of the image. This algorithm is efficient at finding the seed locations but does not provide the most accurate segmentation. So for images that were successfully segmented by the watershed method we then applied the random walker algorithm to them. The random walker requires colour images and starts with a seed and then expands outwards to look for neighbours to segment the image. The seeds from the watershed algorithm are used as the starting points for the random walker. The final segmented images and their properties are obtained from the random walker algorithm, as it provides accurate segmentation with clear boundaries. After the image segmentation step, we are left with 70\u2009823 candidates. These candidates were visually inspected and reduced to 156.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We then applied a second set of colour cuts that incorporate the <em>W</em>1 and <em>W</em>2 bands from <em>WISE</em> (equation\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-update78118_math1536290956284\"></span><a href=\"#update78118_math1536290956284\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a>; using a matching radius of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1\\, \\text{arcsec}$|\u2060</span>), based on fig. 3 of Ostrovski et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), to further narrow down the sample. The <em>WISE</em> magnitudes are in the Vega system. The conversions for the <em>WISE</em> data are <em>W</em>1<sub>AB</sub> = <em>W</em>1<sub>Vega</sub> + 2.699 and <em>W</em>2<sub>AB</sub> = <em>W</em>2<sub>Vega</sub> + 3.339 that are given by Jarrett et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). Candidates for which the value of <em>W</em>1 is an upper limit were also removed, as their colours are not reliable. <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update78118_math1536290956284\" content-id=\"update78118_math1536290956284\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n&amp;-&amp;0.5 \\lt (i - W1) \\lt 2.5\\nonumber \\\\&amp;-&amp;0.2 \\lt (g-i) \\lt 1\\nonumber \\\\&amp;-&amp;0.1 \\lt (W1-W2) \\lt 1.2. \r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">These final cuts yielded 35 candidates that were all then visually inspected to select the final sample of 18 candidates for spectroscopic follow-up. We were able to observe 16 of the 18 candidates and these are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> together with a summary of the follow-up data and outcome. In short, one of the candidates remains inconclusive, and will require higher resolution spectroscopy or deeper imaging to finalize its classification. Fifteen objects are found to be contaminants, including eight star pairs, three QSO+star pairs, one probable QSO pair, and three galaxies. Based on the performance so far it is clear that this method requires further improvements, especially in the rejection of stellar contaminants, in order to be competitive with other methods in terms of purity.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121092675 id=\"121092675\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>7 SUMMARY STATISTICS OF THE 2016 STRIDES FOLLOW-UP CAMPAIGN</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition to the OST introduced by Agnello (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), and the morphological technique described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>, other techniques were developed by members of the STRIDES collaboration. Their selection techniques and results of follow-up are described in other papers of this series (Anguita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Ostrovski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Overall, taking into account all selection methods, 117 DES-selected candidates were observed. Seven were confirmed as lensed quasars, including Two quads, seven were classified as NIQs. For 27, the observations were inconclusive, and the rest were rejected as contaminants.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The scale of the follow-up is sufficient to get a first assessment of the success rate of our candidate selection techniques, and compare it with previous searches. The overall success rate across all techniques is in the range of 6\u201335\u00a0per\u2009cent. This is a good success rate considering that the selection is purely photometric and no spectroscopic pre-selection is applied. For comparison, the most recently completed large-scale search for lensed quasars is the SQLS (Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Starting from a sample of 50\u2009836 spectroscopically confirmed quasars, they identified 520 candidates based on colour and morphology. Thirty (including 26 in the so-called statistical sample) of those were confirmed as lensed quasars. One important class of contaminants were 81/520 QSO pairs, i.e. approximately 16\u00a0per\u2009cent. Another important class of contaminants were QSO+star (at least 100), to which one should probably add most of the objects classified as \u2018no lens\u2019 based on imaging data (158; spectroscopic classification is not available for this class; these are most likely to be QSO+star; Oguri private communication), A few objects could not be confirmed as lenses due to small separation (9), although some of them could very well be lenses. Thus, the overall success rate is at least 6\u00a0per\u2009cent but possibly a little higher. QSO+star class comprises at least 19\u00a0per\u2009cent of the spurious candidates, and perhaps as high as 50\u00a0per\u2009cent. We refer to the individual papers of this series for a breakdown in the various class of contaminants for the STRIDES searches.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A more recent search is that carried out by the SDSS-III BOSS quasar lens survey (BQLS; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Similarly to SQLS, they start from spectroscopically confirmed quasars and look for evidence for lensing. In their initial study, they confirmed as lenses 13 of their 55 best candidates, i.e. a success rate of 20\u00a0per\u2009cent. Of the top 55 candidates, 11 are confirmed quasar pairs, some of which might be unrecognized lenses.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition, we can compare the number of forecasted lenses with the number of confirmed lenses to roughly estimate the completeness of our search so far, keeping in mind that the searches were conducted on partial and different DES data releases. The two search algorithms presented in this paper were applied to the Y1A1 DES data release, which covers approximately 1800\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>, i.e. 36\u00a0per\u2009cent of the DES footprint, shallower than full depth. The algorithm presented in paper II (Anguita et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) was applied to the Y1+Y2 footprint, corresponding to approximately the entire DES footprint, shallower than full depth. The algorithm presented in paper III (Ostrovski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) was applied to the part of the Y3 data release that overlaps with the VISTA-VHS survey (approximately half the entire DES footprint, shallower than full depth).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Considering only the brighter systems (<em>i</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a020.2 or brighter) that should have been detectable at reduced depth, we expected (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a> roughly 60 lensed quasars, including 15 quads. We confirmed 7 lenses, including 2 quads (possibly 8/3 if one wishes to include DESJ2346-5203). It is unlikely that more quads are hiding amongst the 33 inconclusive systems (including NIQs), as those generally tend to be easily to confirm due to their peculiar morphology. Thus, we conclude that a large fraction of quads (and possibly doubles) brighter than <em>i</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a020.2 remains to be found in the DES footprint, motivating additional searches in subsequent DES data releases and follow-up campaigns. This conclusion is consistent with the discovery of doubles and quads in the DES footprint, before (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Lin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Ostrovski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and after (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>) the conclusion of the Fall 2016 campaign. At the moment of this writing, considering all known lensed quasars within the DES footprint including those discovered before and after the STRIDES Fall 2016 campaign, there is a good agreement between the forecasts and the observations for <em>i</em> \u2272 18.5 (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>). Beyond this limit the number of known lensed quasars increases much more slowly than forecasted, suggesting that many lenses remain to be found.</p>                        <a id=\"121092681\" scrollto-destination=\"121092681\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/m_sty2329fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&amp;Signature=Ng-6mkc4K2B8dzi9Gx3CPoRtNVFV4U7zHUYiynmtP25mnFD~7ALnZwERSD2XAU-wL~pCRNkr90DOCvMBueDjy05f2vQdE607VynTAInrCRS9y3yIoelQasqulIw2AkhpLu1OBYLg1Z0rFiSNxpdflh9H9M6mn6KDXPXW~0SgcxMTzX-tza98B4HpFFaafpKz9gTtZSalhCeDKi1ynx3B884HFJ2-kMCEsPQZ~~zPfsX8cUsXVCiq6ORLA8Uh6ZoV7dvmL2mekOavhqLM0WvhAy8lauYfdbQGXXnPLnSKl~m3lvDn810fJGgd59VRhvHKBjIKKeCfBDXM21AUHuBmrg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison between known lenses (including those discovered before and after the Fall 2016 STRIDES campaign) within the DES footprint (solid lines) and OM10 forecasts (dotted lines). The thin blue lines indicate doubles (excluding NIQs), and the thick red lines indicate quads. The vertical axis shows the cumulative number of lenses, while the horizontal axis shows the total i-band magnitude measured within a $5\\, \\text{arcsec}$-diameter aperture in DES images.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121092681/sty2329fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121092681\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/sty2329fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&Signature=nAsbw62D4vEcUHhE76TLXBPN7MlR9pVmi0eLEAzV7QCPD7FQZEKOLLW5qINZBs6vkQ0EwB9rNT~ed6ftqlgjZwOYQQ8njKlmEuYMP07Wq~V3IlqqVNz3Y7SINhEnp2sV9BFy32qYoAfgjpDobOu4gYOf~GdOkc8Ku~oBtdbq4JGQm3ObhiLWs7SlzI7YqgPrG1OuLhOsV5eOwX7arXsSbE2-3hV6~ueTuOipEJ5PYOHF~hCKYn2p8Tqb7KcUNvdhrqLwFuttA-O30Manm6B3ab5jup0gX8h8w5nH~sJKCHOLs1whutHIGnB0AGHSoJEFKo1O5Z7wz0w9aVhfhAr8~g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121092681&ar=5078885&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison between known lenses (including those discovered before and after the Fall 2016 STRIDES campaign) within the DES footprint (solid lines) and OM10 forecasts (dotted lines). The thin blue lines indicate doubles (excluding NIQs), and the thick red lines indicate quads. The vertical axis shows the cumulative number of lenses, while the horizontal axis shows the total <em>i</em>-band magnitude measured within a <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$5\\, \\text{arcsec}$|</span>-diameter aperture in DES images.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/m_sty2329fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&amp;Signature=Ng-6mkc4K2B8dzi9Gx3CPoRtNVFV4U7zHUYiynmtP25mnFD~7ALnZwERSD2XAU-wL~pCRNkr90DOCvMBueDjy05f2vQdE607VynTAInrCRS9y3yIoelQasqulIw2AkhpLu1OBYLg1Z0rFiSNxpdflh9H9M6mn6KDXPXW~0SgcxMTzX-tza98B4HpFFaafpKz9gTtZSalhCeDKi1ynx3B884HFJ2-kMCEsPQZ~~zPfsX8cUsXVCiq6ORLA8Uh6ZoV7dvmL2mekOavhqLM0WvhAy8lauYfdbQGXXnPLnSKl~m3lvDn810fJGgd59VRhvHKBjIKKeCfBDXM21AUHuBmrg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison between known lenses (including those discovered before and after the Fall 2016 STRIDES campaign) within the DES footprint (solid lines) and OM10 forecasts (dotted lines). The thin blue lines indicate doubles (excluding NIQs), and the thick red lines indicate quads. The vertical axis shows the cumulative number of lenses, while the horizontal axis shows the total i-band magnitude measured within a $5\\, \\text{arcsec}$-diameter aperture in DES images.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig7.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121092681/sty2329fig7.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig7.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121092681\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/sty2329fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&Signature=nAsbw62D4vEcUHhE76TLXBPN7MlR9pVmi0eLEAzV7QCPD7FQZEKOLLW5qINZBs6vkQ0EwB9rNT~ed6ftqlgjZwOYQQ8njKlmEuYMP07Wq~V3IlqqVNz3Y7SINhEnp2sV9BFy32qYoAfgjpDobOu4gYOf~GdOkc8Ku~oBtdbq4JGQm3ObhiLWs7SlzI7YqgPrG1OuLhOsV5eOwX7arXsSbE2-3hV6~ueTuOipEJ5PYOHF~hCKYn2p8Tqb7KcUNvdhrqLwFuttA-O30Manm6B3ab5jup0gX8h8w5nH~sJKCHOLs1whutHIGnB0AGHSoJEFKo1O5Z7wz0w9aVhfhAr8~g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121092681&ar=5078885&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig7.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison between known lenses (including those discovered before and after the Fall 2016 STRIDES campaign) within the DES footprint (solid lines) and OM10 forecasts (dotted lines). The thin blue lines indicate doubles (excluding NIQs), and the thick red lines indicate quads. The vertical axis shows the cumulative number of lenses, while the horizontal axis shows the total <em>i</em>-band magnitude measured within a <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$5\\, \\text{arcsec}$|</span>-diameter aperture in DES images.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The public data releases (Gaia Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) of the <em>Gaia</em> satellite (Gaia Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) have provided another powerful tool in the arsenal of the lens quasar finding community. <em>Gaia</em>\u2019s high-resolution positions and proper motions have been shown to be extremely powerful by themselves (Krone-Martins et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) and especially in combination with optical and mid-IR images for identifying lensed quasars and reject contaminants (Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>; Agnello &amp; Spiniello <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Lemon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). The fast turnaround of these discoveries after the data releases is very encouraging for STRIDES both in terms of the prospects of completeness and success rate of targeted follow-up.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, we can make a further comparison between the forecast and the properties of entire sample, by looking at the quasar redshift distribution. Given the small number statistics, we combine both confirmed lenses and NIQs, assuming that they are drawn from the same distribution, even though this of course will need to be revisited at the end of the STRIDES multiyear effort. The distribution is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>. As forecasted, the distribution peaks at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub><em>s</em></sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a02, and drops off below 1 and above 3. Whereas the numbers are still too small for a quantitative comparison between forecast and detections, the qualitative agreement is encouraging, especially because contrary to the SDSS searches we did not rely on <em>u</em>-band imaging or spectroscopic information for selection of candidates.</p>                        <a id=\"121092684\" scrollto-destination=\"121092684\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" data-section=\"121092684\" class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/m_sty2329fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&amp;Signature=OZMPpnE~mRTE9DgSsuBP-eqrjGPe2VT~RpuZIt-0QUQGBTXhRf5tEvL02EKtYQq6gOS7GeMu9Oeh9LkfdvPJhii1bUcmk-LXcf5QHmJcHKuYpiNrV-FkyiIdTQTfEVi8m8Y18ezccjO4CtLD0-1i5ISYQDkbUIlU92FO5jYaxDGs2QU~QmrBa3Rf57fBSNwue4t7U6rlZB0TAulb5XmK1T3E~DzDzXKxLjwSA1ylXxFWctIjyz4R2fgz4lCdXM9rxfNg5Rc-XwHqyC~EkDKyXs30e7WAIZ5bb3B-za0tRA7S5m1gGv1BhqrEptM~b4CTOxw2h5c~pjl-RgfMvmZfgg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of quasar redshifts for confirmed lenses (shaded histogram) and NIQs (open histogram).\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig8.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/121092684/sty2329fig8.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig8.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"121092684\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/481/1/10.1093_mnras_sty2329/1/sty2329fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611465580&Signature=f~UdvBw7BZg6T4dS6pNWmFFwruycPSAVwA2SbmpqutkCp2K6fec5~gv-Lgrv0uEtrFSnGkVMgn4xjEjwmVSZ3CQy1RudIbfLQyBTYNklETFSXD8AHa2GQBPePiVZ~xr-J6gQ1~Vwygt7Cto2IJXLrI7rFrTDA3r9NH8x7P1CUWolobCi9owgxgwAMof6Qg5lwfqiJ~w0~-MtRp~IjikpkBON03sGB~26H38ViGEf~xfv--4SMsFENxmxbTvOCz388UGQvAiCOUrEcEkuFfIH-Ba28~8memWByuampeORnAUk4DPyidC0Y8CdJXG16tH1YIK3BQA7k5pVrxsW~dfr~Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=121092684&ar=5078885&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty2329fig8.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of quasar redshifts for confirmed lenses (shaded histogram) and NIQs (open histogram).</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121092685 id=\"121092685\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec8>8 SUMMARY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have presented an overview of the STRIDES programme, an external collaboration of the Dark Energy Survey aimed at finding and studying strongly lensed quasars, and outlined some of the results of the first comprehensive follow-up campaign. The main results of this paper can be summarized as follows: <ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our detailed forecasts indicate that about 50 quads and 200 doubles should be detectable in DES data. Of those, approximately 60 should be bright enough for time delay measurements with 1\u20132\u2009m class telescopes, while the rest will require a 4\u2009m class telescope for monitoring. All the systems will be bright enough to measure stellar velocity dispersion with 8\u201310\u2009m class telescopes.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The STRIDES lens classification scheme is presented. In addition to confirmed lenses, and inconclusive systems, we adopt the class of NIQ to identify inconclusive targets that are particularly promising for additional follow-up.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We detail the results of the follow-up of 42 targets selected by two of the search techniques (Outlier Selection and Morphological; OST and MT, respectively). One of those is a candidate quadruply imaged quasar (DESJ2346-5203; see the next bullet item), 11 are inconclusive, and 30 are contaminants. The contaminants are dominated by QSO+star pairs for the OST and by star pairs for MT.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Based on the analysis of 0.4 seeing Gemini-S images of the candidate quad DESJ2346-5203, and we conclude that this is not a quadruply imaged quasar in a classic configuration. If it is a multiply-imaged quasar the morphology requires a complex deflector or extreme flux ratio anomalies. High-resolution imaging or spectroscopy is required to definitely rule out (or confirm) this system as a lens.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We summarize the results of our Fall 2016 observing campaign with the Keck, SOAR, NTT, Shane Telescopes. In total, we followed up 117 targets, confirming 7 lenses including 2 quads, and found 7 NIQs. The observations were inconclusive for 27 targets, yielding a success rate in the range of 6\u201335\u00a0per\u2009cent. This success rate is comparable with those of other large searches for lensed quasars even though neither spectroscopic information nor <em>u</em>-band imaging was available to help in the selection.</p></li></ul></p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In conclusion, the results of the first extensive STRIDES follow-up campaign demonstrate that multiply-imaged quasars can be found efficiently from wide field imaging survey even in the absence of <em>u</em>-band or spectroscopic pre-selection. At the conclusion of our multiyear campaign, with the investment of telescope time to carry out imaging and spectroscopic follow-up of DES-selected targets, STRIDES should more than double the current a sample of known lensed quasars, and thus enable significant progress in our understanding of the nature of dark matter and dark energy.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121092688 id=\"121092688\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" >ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The authors thank the referee for a constructive report that helped improved the paper. Based in part on observations made with ESO Telescopes at the La Silla Paranal Observatory. This publication makes use of data products from the <em>WISE</em>, which is a joint project of the University of California, Los Angeles, and the Jet Propulsion Laboratory/California Institute of Technology, funded by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121092696 id=\"121092696\" class=\"backfootnotegroup-title\" >Footnotes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">STRIDES is a Dark Energy Survey Broad External Collaboration; PI: Treu. <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://strides.astro.ucla.edu\" target=\"_blank\">http://strides.astro.ucla.edu</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">During the follow-up campaign, non-DES targets selected from other surveys were also targeted. Those are described by papers outside of this series (e.g. Schechter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; Agnello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018a</a>; Ostrovski et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Williams et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn3\" class=\"end-note-link\">3</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://github.com/drphilmarshall/OM10/\" target=\"_blank\">https://github.com/drphilmarshall/OM10/</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn4\" class=\"end-note-link\">4</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"https://github.com/tcollett/LensPop\" target=\"_blank\">https://github.com/tcollett/LensPop</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn5\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn5\" class=\"end-note-link\">5</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Compilation assembled by one of us (CL). The compilation by Ducourant et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), not yet publicly available, reports 243 confirmed systems, even though a direct comparison is difficult since the criteria for confirmation are unpublished and may be different from ours. Regardless of which compilation one chooses to compare, the STRIDES forecasted sample is larger than the number of currently known lensed quasars.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn6\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn6\" class=\"end-note-link\">6</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The <em>r</em> \u2212 <em>i</em> cut is slightly different than the original one due to a small computing error.</p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=121092703 id=\"121092703\" class=\"backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list\"><div content-id=\"bib1\" data-legacy-id=\"bib1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib1\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib1\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Abbott</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">T. "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2018MNRAS.481.1041T", "Tables status": "Complete", "Inspection status": "Incomplete", "Paper Overview": {"abstract": "The primary goals of the STRong lensing Insights into the Dark Energy Survey (STRIDES) collaboration are to measure the dark energy equation of state parameter and the free streaming length of dark matter. To this aim, STRIDES is discovering strongly lensed quasars in the imaging data of the Dark Energy Survey and following them up to measure time delays, high resolution imaging, and spectroscopy sufficient to construct accurate lens models. In this paper, we first present forecasts for STRIDES. Then, we describe the STRIDES classification scheme, and give an overview of the Fall 2016 follow-up campaign. We continue by detailing the results of two selection methods, the outlier selection technique and a morphological algorithm, and presenting lens models of a system that could possibly be a lensed quasar in an unusual configuration. We conclude with the summary statistics of the Fall 2016 campaign. Including searches presented in companion papers (Anguita et al.; Ostrovski et al.), STRIDES followed up 117 targets identifying 7 new strongly lensed systems, and 7 nearly identical quasars, which could be confirmed as lenses by the detection of the lens galaxy. 76 candidates were rejected and 27 remain otherwise inconclusive, for a success rate in the range of 6-35 per cent. This rate is comparable to that of previous searches like SDSS Quasar Lens Search even though the parent data set of STRIDES is purely photometric and our selection of candidates cannot rely on spectroscopic information.", "start_page": "1041", "authors": ["Treu, T.", "Agnello, A.", "Baumer, M.                         </span>\r\n                                        <span class=\"al-author-name-more js-flyout-wrap\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                                            <a 95616, USA</div>\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"info-card-search-label\">\r\n        Search for other works by this author on:\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n<div class=\"info-card-search   // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n                                                <option       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input
